posts.title: Building PMO Operations from Scratch
posts.excerpt: Lessons learned from establishing Agile PMO frameworks for enterprise digital transformation teams.
posts.body:
## The Challenge

When I joined Allergan Aesthetics, there was no formal PMO in place. Digital projects were managed ad-hoc across 6 departments with 23 stakeholders, each with their own workflow and priorities.

## Building the Foundation

The first step was establishing a **governance framework** that felt lightweight enough for teams to adopt, yet robust enough to provide visibility to leadership.

### Key Principles

- **Start small, scale fast** — We began with a single pilot team before rolling out across all departments
- **Tool-agnostic processes** — The framework works regardless of whether teams use JIRA, Azure DevOps, or Asana
- **Data-driven decisions** — Every process was designed to generate actionable metrics

## Results

Within 18 months, we were managing a portfolio of **93 cross-functional projects** with:

1. 40% reduction in project delivery times
2. 70% improvement in stakeholder response times
3. Clear visibility into resource allocation across all departments

> The key insight: PMO success isn't about enforcing rigid processes — it's about creating a shared language for how work gets done.

## Lessons Learned

The biggest lesson? **Change management is harder than project management.** Getting teams to adopt new processes requires empathy, patience, and relentless communication.

posts.title: The Future of AI in Project Management
posts.excerpt: How multi-agent AI systems are reshaping how we plan, execute, and deliver complex digital projects.
posts.body:
## The Shift is Happening

AI is no longer a buzzword in project management — it's becoming an essential tool. From automated risk assessment to intelligent resource allocation, AI is fundamentally changing how we deliver projects.

## Multi-Agent Systems

The most exciting development is **multi-agent AI systems** — architectures where multiple specialized AI agents collaborate on complex tasks:

- **Planning Agent** — Analyzes historical data to create realistic project timelines
- **Risk Agent** — Continuously monitors project health and flags potential issues
- **Communication Agent** — Drafts status reports and stakeholder updates

### How They Work Together

These agents don't operate in isolation. They share context, challenge each other's assumptions, and produce outputs that are more nuanced than any single AI could achieve.

## Practical Applications Today

You don't need to wait for the future to benefit from AI in PM:

1. **Sprint planning** — Use AI to analyze velocity data and suggest realistic commitments
2. **Risk identification** — Train models on your historical project data to predict common failure patterns
3. **Status reporting** — Automate the collection and summarization of project metrics

## The Human Element

> AI won't replace project managers. But project managers who use AI will replace those who don't.

The most important skill for modern PMs isn't technical — it's the ability to **translate between human needs and AI capabilities**.
